1479214893509365772.text: One year ago, just a few hours after the Capitol was attacked in a deadly attempt to prevent the peaceful transfer of power, I took to the House Floor to remind my colleagues that defending democracy is not—and should not be—a partisan task. https://t.co/eslPY8RfWm

1479139293679521793.text:
We are in the midst of the most perilous times in the history of our fragile democracy. But we are not powerless to stop it. 

The House has passed critical voting rights legislation to protect every American's access to the ballot box—it is up to the Senate to meet this moment.

1479139291137818626.text: The Big Lie has been used as pretext all over the country—including Arizona—for efforts to restrict access to the ballot, install elected officials willing to openly ignore the legal votes of the people, and to adopt ways to overturn the results of future elections.

1479139287480389632.text:
That day, the domestic terrorists failed. 

But it was the beginning of the Big Lie and a dangerous plot to overturn future elections. The fraudulent conspiracy that the election was anything but safe, secure and fair has infected politics at every level.

1479139284896694273.text: I’ll never forget the sacrifices that @CapitolPolice and @DCPoliceDept officers made that day. More than 100 officers were injured, and five tragically lost their lives in the days and weeks that followed.

1479139282249994241.text: One year ago, a violent mob of domestic terrorists stormed the Capitol with a single goal: overturn a free and fair election—the bedrock of our democracy.

1394785781428916224.text: The road to peace remains a long one, but we can take the first step today by working toward an immediate cease-fire and rededicating ourselves to a better future for Israelis and Palestinians alike.

1394785780023844867.text: And Israel’s leaders, including Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu so long as he remains in power, must hold far-right Israeli extremists accountable, actively work to calm tensions within the region, and seek a stronger future for Palestinians.

1394785779231166466.text: Peace cannot happen as long as Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, now 16 years into his “four-year term,” cancels election after election to hold onto power and lacks the legitimacy to negotiate an enduring peace.

1394785778434252800.text: But peace cannot happen as long as Hamas calls for another genocide of the Jewish people, refuses to recognize Israel’s right to exist, and remains in power. Gaza—and all Palestinians—must be freed from Hamas.

1394785777616310278.text: The conflict in the Middle East, which has caused so much pain for Palestinians and Israelis alike, must be solved—and it must become a higher priority for the international community, including the United States.

1394785776827834371.text: It is a terrible tragedy, though, that so many Palestinian civilians have lost their lives during this conflict. Hamas has a long and well-documented history of cruelly using innocent Palestinians as shields and hiding weapons stockpiles in schools, hospitals and neighborhoods.

1394785776056012803.text: Several of Hamas’s top commanders have been neutralized, and its ability to carry out significant attacks in the near future has been diminished. That is a positive step.

1394785775259107330.text: If the United States were attacked by terrorists, we would defend ourselves and Israel has the same right to do so—period. To suggest otherwise holds Israel to a different standard than is expected of any other nation.

1394785774466392065.text: Hamas’s indiscriminate attacks have not only killed Jewish and Arab Israelis but even Palestinians they rule over as one-fifth of their rockets fall directly into Gaza.

1394785773694693376.text: This latest round of cyclical violence escalated when Hamas’s terrorist regime in Gaza launched rocket attacks with the intent to kill Israeli citizens.

1394785772822274054.text:
It is time for an immediate cease-fire between Israel and Hamas, and I hope President Biden will actively work toward that goal.
https://t.co/M5nd8ey2YT

1336402118211751936.text: Masks alone are not a silver bullet, but they help. They save lives. In the long road ahead, I won’t stop fighting to make sure Arizona has a clear strategy to keep people healthy and get our economy back on track. This is the most basic step we can take. We have to act.

1336402117293117446.text: This isn’t about politics, it’s about public health. It’s about whether we can trust our state leaders to manage a crisis and listen to experts. It's clear to me the only way to get the governor to do the right thing is to hold his feet to the fire.

1336402116429090819.text: I’ve called for a statewide mandate for months now, and so have countless others – doctors, nurses, teachers, epidemiologists. Yet, Arizona remains one of a few holdout states. It’s costing lives.

1336402115531591682.text: To be clear: It wouldn’t impact rental assistance that goes to cities or federal help in unemployment insurance, which are different pots of money. It affects the state and local government aid alone.

1336402114600427522.text: To incentivize holdout states, counties, and cities let’s send a message: If you want federal relief funds, mandate masks. That’s good news for most of Arizona counties and cities, which would still get funds and split what the Ducey Administration would otherwise receive.

1336402113598021632.text: More than 12,000 new COVID-19 cases in Arizona today. Nearly 7,000 Arizonans have died. Every alarm bell is sounding, yet the governor still refuses to adopt the most basic public health policy measure to keep people safe: a mask mandate.

1336091807365492736.text:
Governors, it’s simple: If you’re not responsible enough to adopt common-sense, science-backed policies, you’re not responsible enough to manage relief funds.

Poor decision-making kills people, overwhelms hospitals, costs jobs, and will soon put more people on the streets.

1336091806568615936.text:
As the COVID crisis reaches new heights, Congress can’t ignore that some governors have made things worse by thwarting science and refusing to adopt mask mandates.

It’s time for a new policy: If states and cities want federal relief funds, they must mandate masks.

1326214511401918467.text: Getting this right isn’t all that hard. But it does take a willingness to embrace science and treat the COVID pandemic as something more than a PR crisis. It’s time for Arizona leaders to step up.

1326214510634393601.text: 5. Modernize unemployment benefits. Many are still hurting from the harsh economic impact of the pandemic, and Arizona has the second-lowest unemployment safety net in the country. That’s unacceptable—the Governor and legislature should take this on now.

1326214509887848449.text: 4. Address the spread in nursing homes and long-term care facilities. Test weekly those who care for our most vulnerable to prioritize health care workers and their patients. If we don’t protect our most vulnerable first, we will fail in this fight.

1326214509145415680.text: 3. Prioritize contact tracing. Arizona has just 5 percent of the number of contact tracers we need to track our spread and identify hotspots. More time has been squandered, but we have the resources to build an effective contact tracing defense. We need to get it done.

1326214508373635078.text: 2. Continue to expand testing and speed up results. As infection rates rise, we need testing to be fast and readily available for free. More testing data will give us a clearer forecast of this virus and allow us to curb the spread.

1326214507614490624.text: 1. Mandate masks statewide—now. I was the first to call for an Arizona mandate in June and it’s still necessary. Masks work and save lives—and they are essential to getting us on the path to a faster recovery.

1326214506855321601.text:
This is one of the worst failures of government leaders in Arizona history. They fell asleep at the wheel during the spring shutdown and failed to prepare for our summer surge. And they’ve failed to prepare for the second wave we all knew was coming.

Here’s what we need to do:

1326214505815134208.text: In Arizona, COVID-19 cases are rising as fast as they did in June. Today we saw our highest number of new cases since July. Hospitals fear they'll soon be overwhelmed. We are on the same deadly path, but state leaders have refused to change course.

1308592377695625218.text: This pandemic won’t end any time soon.  Hardships will continue. Congress needs to once again work across the aisle to deliver real relief to Arizona, and state leaders need to be good partners in weathering this storm. It’s time for bickering to end. It’s time to take action.

1308592376923873280.text: Trump’s inaction trickled down to state leaders here in Arizona, who failed to take appropriate action to protect lives and livelihoods. For weeks, we were the world’s leading hotspot for COVID-19. Too many died needlessly.

1308592376135385093.text:

1291520110075744256.text: After graduating from Phoenix Union High School, Henry and his three brothers joined the U.S. Army to fight in World War II. Henry and his crew flew 29 successful bombing missions in Europe, including being part of the D-Day invasion on the beaches of Normandy.

We just passed H.R. 2339, the Protecting American Lungs and Reversing the Youth Tobacco Epidemic Act to:
🚭address the new youth tobacco epidemic 
🚭prohibit the manufacturing and sale of all flavored tobacco products
🚭ban companies from marketing e-cigarettes to youth under 21.

1233441777174163456.text: The dramatic rise in the number of middle and high school students using e-cigarettes has reversed the progress made in recent decades to curb tobacco use by kids and teens. We must act now to prevent the loss of an entirely new generation to a lifetime of nicotine addiction.

1233441776242917376.text: It's no surprise that 97 percent of kids and teens using e-cigarettes use flavored e-cigarettes. Flavors like Rocket Popscicle, Tropical Fruit, Watermelon Wave, Electric Lemonade, Gummi Bear, and Blue Raz are being marketed to reach younger and younger audiences.

1233441774858838019.text: Today, more than 5.3 million young people are using e-cigarettes, including 1 in 4 high school students. That number skyrocketed by 3 million just in the last 2 years. E-cigarettes have very high levels of nicotine, putting kids at a high risk of developing nicotine addiction.

1113869159782387715.text: A video from the Governor’s @AzMxCom sums it up: "The port of entry has become the catalyst for economic development and opportunities here at the border." Watch here: https://t.co/7h4BCQRqAU

1113869159178428424.text: The automotive industry in Arizona and Sonora produces 1,488 vehicles daily, supporting more than 50,600 employees.

1113869158452740098.text: Together, Arizona and Mexico are leaders in the automotive industry, importing $968 million and $761 million in auto parts in 2016 – net trade of nearly $1.7 billion annually.

1113869157882302464.text: Arizona’s expanded ports of entry are driving investment in infrastructure. Nearly $60 million of private investment has resulted from improvements to border infrastructure in Nogales for warehouses and distribution centers to support international commerce.

1113869157160968194.text: Nearly 3.8 million people from Mexico choose Arizona as a travel destination annually, which represents the largest segment of international tourism to our state. Visitors from Mexico contribute between 60%-70% of sales tax revenue in our border communities.

1113869156582141960.text: Arizona’s infrastructure supports international trade and tourism with six international border ports of entry, including one of the nation’s largest commercial ports, the Mariposa Port of Entry in Nogales.

1113869156091297794.text: Arizona’s two-way trade with Mexico was $15.4 billion in 2017: nearly $7.5 billion in exports and $7.9 billion in imports.

1113869155495817217.text: Since 2012, we've worked hard to repair Arizona's once badly damaged relationship with our largest trading partner. Here are some facts from the Governor’s @AzMxCom, for those who need a refresher:

1113869154887643138.text: It seems some in Washington and Arizona have forgotten how important trade with Mexico is to our state’s economy. That’s troubling. A border shutdown today—or in the future—would be devastating for Arizona.

1088522294677422081.text: Over the weekend, I met with nonprofit leaders in Arizona who work with victims of domestic violence. Their federal funding is critical, and without it, some are being forced to turn people away. This shutdown is hurting our most vulnerable—it has to end. https://t.co/Ja5SFmNfXd

1087522855032627200.text: Thank you to the individuals who joined me this afternoon and spoke so openly and honestly. Thank you for continuing to care and serve, even in the toughest conditions. We are indebted to the work you and countless others do every day.

1087522683666001920.text: I’m headed back to Washington tomorrow to share these stories and advocate for the people I heard from today—and the hundreds of thousands of others impacted by this needless shutdown. There’s just no way around it, we have to get our government working again. https://t.co/SgzRDSs0BC

1087522295688646657.text: But they also shared with me their new stark reality: Coming home with no paycheck in sight is hurting their families. Some are considering paying penalties to dip into retirement. Others are concerned about accessing their health care benefits. The effects are serious and real. https://t.co/O4FRQ7dDjc

1087521634993561600.text: Despite the furloughs, despite the low morale for those forced to work without pay—many of these individuals were most upset that the shutdown has stalled or halted the critical services they provide the American people. https://t.co/Fh2TkbV8HO

1087521400011804672.text: Several employees and service providers are looking ahead and realizing that the shutdown will disrupt their work plans and budgets for the rest of the year. The consequences they fear will fall back to our residents: from forgone airport safety trainings to wildfire prevention. https://t.co/VoPZOtOBqL

1087520808862474243.text: This afternoon I met with more than a dozen Arizonans affected by the government shutdown. Each described to me the ways in which they feel held hostage each day this shutdown continues—their stories were both heartbreaking and frustrating. https://t.co/IWRc0JHyJY

1087028105615732738.text: Next week, I will once again vote to re-open the government. We will continue to put forward constructive, reasonable and bipartisan solutions to end the shutdown and get our government working again for the American people.

1087027957783281667.text: Nearly 90 percent of @DHSgov employees—those on the front lines—are working without pay. 53,000 TSA employees, 54,000 ICE officers, and 42,000 Coast Guard active duty members. It’s immoral and it puts our safety at risk.

1087027798911389702.text: The @USEEOC—the agency that makes sure employees are protected from race, sex, religion, sexual orientation or gender discrimination—is closed. Mediations have been cancelled and pending cases are being suspended.

1087027608443858944.text: Thousands of federal employees responsible for enforcing public health, safety, consumer rights and environmental laws are on furlough. Food safety is at risk, and the shutdown is creating a backlog of approvals for new innovative prescription drugs and medical devices.

1087027374728859649.text: E-Verify has been unavailable during the shutdown, which means more than 750,000 private sector employers who rely on the service can’t use it to hire new workers and fill jobs. That’s just plain harmful to our economy.

1087026064356986880.text: Most immigration judges are on furlough. Cases are essentially frozen. Our courts are already facing a massive backlog of 800,000+ pending cases, with new ones now rescheduled several years out. Considering the president’s posture on border security, this disruption is absurd.

1087025935814180865.text: Grant payments from @TheJusticeDept are now in jeopardy. Domestic violence shelters across the nation—many of which rely on federal grant funds each month—could struggle to keep their doors open and be forced to turn away women and children.

1087025690996850693.text: We’re about to enter the second month of this needless shutdown. Tomorrow, I’ll meet with people in AZ who are directly feeling the negative impacts. But I want to take a moment to share how the shutdown’s effect on law enforcement and safety organizations is hurting people.

1086043097564352518.text: Two great assignments for working on issues that matter to the future of Arizona. I look forward to working with communities across the state to deliver results on the Transportation & Infrastructure and Judiciary committees. https://t.co/b8NPYEqSIM

1085382557632552960.text: Honored to learn this evening that I’ll be serving on the House Judiciary Committee—a key assignment for Arizona as we work to reform our nation’s broken immigration system. I’m excited to get to work.

1084967712663715840.text: 24 days of this shutdown has left many American families wondering how they will cover their basic costs of living. We’ve heard from a number of residents feeling scared and hurt, and who are asking us to restore certainty to their lives. Enough is enough. #EndTheShutdown

1084204555917844480.text: We got to work on day one to re-open the government and get it working again for the American people. And we wasted no time our first week, coming together to create real, bipartisan results. https://t.co/4yF4FoUqPi

1082690279604396032.text: Eight years after Tucson, we'll do more than hold a moment of silence. Today we offer a bill to require universal background checks for gun sales. I'm proud to stand with @GabbyGiffords, @ShuttleCDRKelly, @RepThompson, and many more to make this common-sense proposal a reality.
